content: Approval of the agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of "Agreement" and "Compact of Free Association" in relation to the United States and the Republic of Palau. It also mentions the amendment of Title I of Public Law 99-658 to include the results of Compact Review. The Agreement and appendices signed by the United States and the Republic of Palau on September 3, 2010 are approved, with the exception of the extension of article X regarding Federal Programs and Services. The Agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau, signed in 2010, includes provisions for withholding funds if Palau withdraws more than $5,000,000 from the trust fund in certain fiscal years. Funding for specific provisions under Section 105 of the Compact is also addressed. Within 30 days of enactment, the Secretary of the Treasury will transfer necessary funds to the Secretary of the Interior for implementing certain provisions of the Compact of Free Association. Authorization of appropriations is provided for subsidizing postal services by the United States Postal Service. The United States Postal Service will provide $1,500,000 annually to the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and the Federated States of Micronesia until 2024. Federal entities under the Compact of Free Association will receive necessary funds for their responsibilities. The United States Postal Service will provide annual funds to the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and the Federated States of Micronesia until 2024. The Act of June 30, 1954 is repealed, and the Agreement's payment schedule and funding are outlined. The United States Postal Service will provide annual funds to Palau, the Marshall Islands, and Micronesia until 2024 under the COMPACT SECTION 211(F) FUND. The Government of the United States will contribute $30,250,000 to the Fund in accordance with a specified schedule until 2023. Additionally, the United States will provide a grant for infrastructure maintenance as outlined in the Agreement. The Government of the United States will provide a grant of $6,912,000 for fiscal year 2014 and $2,000,000 annually from 2015 to 2024 to establish the Infrastructure Maintenance Fund. The Government of Palau will match these contributions with $150,000 quarterly from 2014 to 2024 for the maintenance of capital improvement projects. The Agreement includes provisions for fiscal year 2014 through 2024, with implementation according to Appendix A. Section 3 of the Agreement pertains to the fiscal consolidation fund. "Section 3 of the Agreement establishes the fiscal consolidation fund." The US Government will provide Palau with $10,000,000 in fiscal year 2014 to reduce government arrears. This is in addition to the economic assistance provided in previous years. The implementation will follow the provisions of the Agreement. The Government of the United States will provide economic assistance to Palau totaling $69,250,000 over the fiscal years 2014 to 2022, with decreasing amounts each year. The agreement includes $3,000,000 in fiscal year 2022 and $2,000,000 in fiscal year 2023 for economic assistance, to be provided in quarterly payments. Additionally, infrastructure projects will be funded according to specified percentages. The agreement includes funding for economic assistance in fiscal years 2022 and 2023, with infrastructure projects also being funded according to specified percentages. The United States will provide grants totaling $40,000,000 to Palau for infrastructure projects over several fiscal years. Additionally, amendments are made to the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003, extending certain programs and laws until 2024. "SEC. 141. PASSPORT REQUIREMENT." "Any person in certain categories may be admitted to the US without regard to specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act, if they have a valid machine-readable passport that meets international standards." The Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands, defined in title 53 of the Trust Territory Code, includes individuals who are citizens of Palau by birth, naturalization, or residency for at least five years. They are considered to have permission from the Secretary of Homeland Security to accept entry into the US. The Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands includes individuals who are citizens of Palau by birth, naturalization, or residency for at least five years. They have permission from the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish habitual residence in the US, subject to non-discriminatory limitations. This does not confer the right to establish residence necessary for naturalization under the Immigration and Nationality Act or petition for benefits for aliens. Citizens of Palau in the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands can establish habitual residence in the US with permission from the Secretary of Homeland Security, but this does not grant them the right to naturalization under the Immigration and Nationality Act or petition for benefits for alien relatives.
